pullRequest.body:
Given an integral domain `R` and its fraction field `K`, we define an `R`-lattice in a `K`-vector space `V` to be a finitely generated `R`-submodule of `V` that generates `V` over `K`. If `R` is a PID a lattice is always a free `R`-module of rank `Module.rank K V`.

The unit group of `R` naturally acts on the type of `R`-lattices in `V`. If `V = Fin 2 â†’ K` and `R` is a discrete valuation ring, the quotient by this action are the vertices of the Bruhat-Tits tree of `GL (Fin 2) K`.

In this PR the predicate `IsLattice` on a submodule `M` is defined and some basic stability properties are shown.

From "Formalizing the Bruhat-Tits tree"

Co-authored by: Judith Ludwig <ludwig@mathi.uni-heidelberg.de>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [ecea34fcf3](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19902/commits/ecea34fcf3273f04b5af8e2f7de4f01637bd0246)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Module.Lattice` (new file)|1180|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsLattice`
`+ NoZeroSMulDivisors.of_algebraMap_injective'`
`+ _root_.Basis.extendOfIsLattice`
`+ _root_.Basis.extendOfIsLattice_apply`
`+ _root_.Submodule.span_range_eq_top_of_injective_of_rank_le`
`+ finite`
`+ finrank_of_pi`
`+ free`
`+ inf`
`+ of_le_of_isLattice_of_fg`
`+ of_rank_le`
`+ rank'`
`+ rank_of_pi`
`+ smul`
`+ sup`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
I think "the intersection of two lattices is a lattice" is also true for Dedekind domains (perhaps more general), but it needs a local-global argument. Do you have plan to formalize it?

> I think "the intersection of two lattices is a lattice" is also true for Dedekind domains (perhaps more general), but it needs a local-global argument. Do you have plan to formalize it?

No, we don't have plans to generalize this.

> > I think "the intersection of two lattices is a lattice" is also true for Dedekind domains (perhaps more general), but it needs a local-global argument. Do you have plan to formalize it?
> 
> No, we don't have plans to generalize this.

I see. I think that is useful in algebraic number theory, e.g. to study the intersections of orders (i.e. subrings which are lattices) and ideals in a number field or a quaternion algebra over a number field, etc. etc.

> > > I think "the intersection of two lattices is a lattice" is also true for Dedekind domains (perhaps more general), but it needs a local-global argument. Do you have plan to formalize it?
> > 
> > 
> > No, we don't have plans to generalize this.
> 
> I see. I think that is useful in algebraic number theory, e.g. to study the intersections of orders (i.e. subrings which are lattices) and ideals in a number field or a quaternion algebra over a number field, etc. etc.

Indeed, and we'd be happy to see `lattices` developed further. Our current project is on formalizing the Bruhat-Tits tree, and for that we work in the setting of a DVR, so our setting is local, not global. (Vertices in the Bruhat-Tits tree are defined as homothety classes of lattices.) This motivates this pull request.
Maybe I'll look at this when I finish currently planned PRs.

> @xroblot can you have a look? There are surely relations with the `IsZLattice` class, that should probably be mentioned in the doc. Thanks!

There are indeed surely connection that should be made with `IsZLattice` and eventually `IsZLattice` should just become a special case of `IsLattice`.  One main difference I can see is though that, for `IsZLattice`, we ask the module to be discrete whereas for `IsLattice`, we ask for it to be finitely generated. If I understand, this definition of lattice has been made because it is the one that appears in  Bruhat-Tits tree, but I am not sure that is the one we want in Mathlib. There was some time ago a discussion on Zulip about what the right generalization of `IsZLattice` should be, it would be great to get the opinion of the people involved in the discussion.

See for example: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/ZLattice.3A.20which.20fields.20do.20we.20care.20about.3F

But I think there was another discussion before that too.
Hmm, I really don't know. We surely don't want several "almost" equivalent definitions. @judithludwig maybe you can ask on Zulip?
I added docstrings in both files.
@xroblot can you have a look? There are surely relations with the `IsZLattice` class, that should probably be mentioned in the doc. Thanks!
@xroblot can you have a look? There are surely relations with the `IsZLattice` class, that should probably be mentioned in the doc. Thanks!

Maybe you can prove a more general result first: a finitely generated `R`-module which contains a lattice is a lattice. And this is just a corollary of it. To prove this, maybe you can generalize `of_rank` (as well as `span_range_eq_top_of_injective_of_rank`) to `of_rank_ge` which requires `Module.rank R M â‰¥ Module.rank K V`.
The lemma you suggest is essentially a one-liner, I added it anyway though. I also changed `of_rank` to `of_rank_le`. Thanks for the suggestions!

```suggestion
    le_trans (by rw [IsLattice.span_eq_top]) (Submodule.span_mono hle)âŸ©
```

```suggestion
  -- any torsion free finite module over a PID is free
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Algebra/Module): definition of `R`-lattices
